chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should preserve the federal, state-run structure of presidential elections but reduce winner-take-all distortions so the result more reliably reflects the nationwide vote and voters in every state matter. A broad middle path is to adopt a national standard for proportional (or otherwise non-winner-take-all) elector allocation, with binding electors and clear, uniform baselines for ballot access, paper records, audits, and automatic recount triggers. States that prefer an incremental transition could align through an improved popular-vote compact, while using ranked-choice ballots for president to ensure the winner has majority-level support and minimize spoiler incentives.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should keep states administering elections but make presidential outcomes track the national popular will more reliably, so fewer voters feel invisible in “safe” states and fewer races hinge on a handful of battlegrounds. A practical bridge is to end winner-take-all by moving to proportional allocation of electors (or adopting the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact once broadly joined), while binding electors to certified results. Whatever path is chosen should set clear national baseline standards for ballot access, paper-backed audits, and automatic recount triggers in close races so the rules are simple, verifiable, and hard to game. Adding ranked-choice voting for president can further reduce spoiler fears and help the winner reflect broad, majority support.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should keep elections run by the states but make the presidential outcome match the national popular vote more reliably, so voters in both “safe” and “swing” states feel their ballot matters and smaller communities aren’t ignored. A practical step is to end winner-take-all by moving to proportional allocation of electors (with a clear path to a national popular-vote solution like the NPV compact if it reaches broad buy-in), while requiring electors to follow certified results. Whatever approach is chosen should include simple, uniform nationwide baselines—secure paper ballots, transparent audits, clear recount triggers, and accessible voting—so results are verifiable, hard to game, and widely trusted.
